chapter : 195 STRAMONIUM


Thorn Apple HAHNEMANN Solanaceae

INTRODUCTION

Stramonium, the last of the great TRIO OFDELIRIUM, is a wonderful remedy obtainedfrom the vegetable kingdom. Thorn apple is verypoisonous, affecting primarily the brain andsecondarily other organs. Hahnemann’s high intelligence penetrated into this aspect of theproblem and transformed this very destructivepoisonous property into a useful unique remedyapplied successfully for the characteristic mentalderangement. It has been found to be very usefulfor the human race for all time to come.

CLINICAL

Apoplexy, Chorea, Delirium tremens, Ecstasy, Epilepsy, Eye affection, Headache,Hysteria, Mania, Meningitis, Stammering, Trismus, Vomiting, etc.

SPHERES OF ACTION

The main seats of action of Stramomium, are nervous system, brain, mind, skin and mucous membrane.

PATHOGENESIS

The action of this agent is very similar to that of Belladonna, except that the sympathetic nervous system is more affected by this drug than by Belladonna. It is apowerful narcotic and antispasmodic. The heart’s action is rendered more irregular thanby Belladonna and the involuntary muscular fibres or the bronchial tubes are relaxed toa great extent. It produces suppressed secretions and excretions of mucous membrane.

CONSTITUTION

Just like Belladonna, Stramonium too is more or less a drug required mostly in acute cases and as such the consideration of constitution of the patient is of little importance.However, it is more adapted to young plethoric persons and especially children in chorea,mania and fever with delirium.

Temperament: Bilious temperament,

Relations with heat and cold: Easily affected by cold in general.

Miasm: Psora is in the background.



GUIDING SYMPTOMS

1. “Painlessness” is a very characteristic and striking feature of Stramonium. There is no pain with most of the complaints (Opium).

2. The patient DESIRES LIGHT AND COMPANY. Cannot bear to be alone for a moment. Always wants light, but dazzling light (e.g. light reflected from a mirror orflowing water) aggravates the troubles.

3. Great LOQUACITY is yet another important guiding symptom (Lach., Podo.). The patient is disposed to talk continuously; incessant and incoherent talking andlaughing, PRAYING,, BESEECHING, ENTREATING, etc.

4. The patient always feels sleepy, but cannot sleep (Bell., Cham. Op.).

5. During delirium and convulsion, there is twitching of single muscle or group of muscles, especially of upper part of the body (Aconite,    Agaricus, Cicuta).

6. Convulsion with consciousness (Nux vom.) is very characteristic of this remedy;renewed by sight of bright light.

7. Vomiting as soon as he raises head from the pillow, or from bright light.

8. The patient feels that his head is scattered about in many pieces.

9. He awakes with a shrinking look as if afraid of the first object seen.

10. Sight of water or anything gjittering or reflected light brings on spasm and convulsion. It is simply intolerable.

11. Mind : Stramonium, the last of the trio, is pre-eminently a high grade ‘delirium remedy. The mental symptoms very commonly found in this important remedy,which would help selection on the basis of similinum, are as follows:—

Loquacity is of the topmost degree in Stramonium. During delirium, the patient talks all the time, sings, makes verses, and raves; nonstop and incoherent talkingand laughing.

In this respect it is very similar to Belladonna and Hyoscydmus, but only differing in degree. Stramonium is very furious. Mania more acute and Congestion is morethan in Hyoscyamus but less than that of Belladonna. However, thereis noinflammation in Stramonium, as is usually found in Belladonna.

The patient has a disposition continuously for PRAYING, BESEECHING AND ENTREATING, especially with suppression of menses in ladies.

THE PATIENT ALWAYS WANTS AND DESIRES LIGHT AND COMPANY. Yet cannot tolerate shining bright object or reflected or dazzling light such as from amirror or flowing water. He cannot bear solitude and darkness; cannot remain in adark room alone.

From the sleep he awakes with a shrinking look as if he is very much afraid of the object first seen. He is too much terrified by hallucinations.

During delirium, the patient gets up and wants to escape and, therefore, he runsaway, and hides himself in a corner, difficult to be located.




Furthermore, he has peculiar imagination that he is many persons; he is lying crosswise; his head is in many pieces and isjying scattered about, etc.

There is strange delusions about his own identity. Thinks that he is very tall, double or a part is missing, etc.

The patient feels that he is seeing ghosts and dangerous animals, hears strange voices and he is in communion with spirits and talks in an unnatural language.When the child is reprimanded its pupils become dilated. Hydrophobia.

12. Ailments fom : Shock, fright, sun, child-birth, suppression of secretions and _ excretion (e.g. menses, urine, etc.).

PARTICULARS

Headache :

Causation: Headache is caused by shock, Sun’s heat or fright.

Location: There is intolerable pain in forehead and over the eyebrows.

Sensation: There is boring pain in forehead and tempjes. Head feels as if scattered about in many pieces.

Modalities: Aggravation: After sleep, in darkness or looking at bright object.

Relieved: By warmth.

Concomitants: Preceded by obscure vision. Rush of blood to head. Raises the head frequently from the pillow. Vertigo with tendency to-fall forward and to left.


Eyes :

Eyes are wide open, prominent and brilliant; pupils are widely dilated; insensible; contortion of eyes and eyelids. Pupils dilate when child is reprimanded. Loss of vision, complains that it is dark andcalls for light. Small objects look large. All objects look black.

Face:

Face is red and hot with cold hands and feet. There is circumscribed redness on the cheeks. (Sang.).Blood rushes to face with an expression of terror. Pale face, sometimes facial expression shows as ifsmiling (Risus sardonicus). Mouth is dry, with viscid saliva; yet aversion to water. Stammering tendency.The patient has to exert himself a long time before he can utter a word. Cannot swallow on account ofspasm of glottis; chewing motion of the mouth.The patient vomits persistently mucus and green bile as soon as he raises head from the pillow

Convulsion :

There is convulsion with consciousness (Nux vom.) which is very striking in this drug. Graceful thythmic motion, convulsion especially of upper extremities and upper part of the body. There istwitching and jerking of single muscle or a group of muscles (Acon., Agaricus, Cicuta, Zincummet.).Chorea with violent pain in left hip. Trembling and twitching of tendons.

The convulsive attack is aggravated by dazzling and shining lights and objects.

The patient has fear of water with excessive aversion to liquids. Spasmodic contraction of throat. Hydrophobia.


Fever :

Although Stramonium is not a fever remedy, it can be thought of in remittent, intermittent and continuous fever, provided the fever is acompanied and associated with furious delirium. During fever, there is coldness of the whole body with redness of face and suppressed urine. In chill stage, there is great sensitiveness to being uncovered. Wants to cover up completely. Chill is withoutthirsts and is followed by heat. The patient sleeps during heat stage and there is violent thirst after wakingup. Heat with anxiety or with thirst and vomiting. There is also profuse sweat which does not afford anyrelief.

Pain is very irregular, generally full, hard and quick, or small and rapid.

During all the stages of fever the patient has VIOLENT AND FURIOUS DELIRIUM which is very characteristic and peculiar in this drug.

General Modalities :

Aggravation: In darkness, when alone, looking at bright or shining objects, after sleep, when attempting to swallow and in forenoon.

Amelioration: From bright light, from company and from warmth.

Relations :

Follows well: After Belladonna, Cuprum, Hyos.

In metrorthagia from retained placenta. Secale cor., often follows when Stramonium fails.

Antidotes: Bellad6nna, Nux vomica, Hyoscyamus, lemon juice and vinegar.

It antidotes: Merc. sol., Plumbum.


chapter: 196 SULPHUR

i et enFlowers of Sulphur HAHNEMANN “S” An ElementBrimstone



INTRODUCTION

Sulphur is one ot the greatest ‘OLYCHRESTS’. IT IS THE KING OFANTIPSORIC HAVING a wide range inHomoeopathic prescribing. Hahnemann says
that Sulphur has reputation as a remedy againstitch perhaps as old as medicine i.e., as early as2000 years ago. Sulphur is a non-metallic yellow,brittle substance. It is found in plenty in Sicilyand Italy. In the organic world, we meet withSulphur everywhere. This element forms anessential component of the albuminoids, a classof compounds contained in all vegetable and animal structures. Sulphur is prepared forHomoeopathic use in two different ways, firstly the flowers of sulphur washed andcleaned, are mixed with alcohol to form the tincture; secondly by triturating flowers ofsulphur with sugar of milk.

CLINICAL

Acne, Anaemia, Asthma, Biliousness, Boils, Brain complaints, Catarrh, Cough,Diarrhoea, Dysentery, Eye affection, Eczema, Emaciation, Enuresis, Epilepsy, Eructation.Eruptions, Feet burning, Perspiring, Fever, Gout, Haemorrhoids, Headache, Liveraffection, Menstrual disorders, Neuralgia, Pleurisy, Pregnancy disorders, Rheumatism,Skin affection,. Throat and Lung affection, Vertigo, Worms, etc.

SPHERES OF ACTION

Its action is centrifugal, from within outwards. It has great affinity for the skin. No remedy has more general, positive and persistent action upon the skin than Sulphur. Itacts pre eminently on the nervous system, also affecting the venous capillary system andthrough it affecting profoundly, the entire vegetative sphere. Mucous membranes alsofeel most severely the influence of Sulphur, especially of eyes, bronchi, urethra andrectum. The portal system also comes under its special influence.

PATHOGENESIS

Subjected to venous plethora, It has portal stasis manifesting as redness at the muco- cutaneous junctions e.g. nostrils, lips, anus, etc. Affecting the skin, it produces heat andburning with severe itching.

CONSTITUTION

Physical make-up: Sulphur is especially suited to lean, stoop-shouldered persons who walk and sit stooping, walk stooping like an old man. STANDING IS THE WORSTPOSITION FOR A SULPHUR PATIENT. They cannot remain standing; every standingposition is very uncomfortable and unbearable.

Dirty, filthy look of the body, prone to skin affections. This type of people have redness of all the external orifices e.g. nostrils, lips, anus, etc.

Temperament: Nervous temperament.

Relation with heat and cold: Sulphur patient is very much sensitive to atmospheric changes. Yet he is accepted as a HOT PATIENT.

Miasm: It is the king of anti-psoric remedies.

Diathesis: Scrofulous diathesis.

GUIDING SYMPTOMS

1. Complaints that are continually relapsing. Patient seems to get almost well, when the disease returns again and again.

2. When carefully selected remedies fail to produce a favourable effect, especially inacute diseases, it frequently serves to rouse the reactive     powers of the system andclears up the case.

3. Standing is the most uncomfortable position for a sulphur patient, they cannot remain standing. Every standing position is uncomfortable and      intolerable.

4. Though a hot patient, yet persistently refuses to take bath.

5. Burning anywhere. and everywhere on the body, general or local, is a great symptom of Sulphur. It is correct to say that “BURNING IS FOR SULPHUR andSULPHUR IS FOR BURNING”. Burning in the soles, palms vertex, eyes, nose,mouth, stomach, all over the skin, in the parts on which he lies. The burning isaggravated from the heat of bed and covering.Nash’s trio of burners are Sulphur, Arsenic and Phosphorus amongst whichSulphur is the leader.The burning of Arsenic is violent and acute and is RELIEVED BY HEAT, exceptinghead, with marked prostration and restlessness. Burning especially in acutediseases (rev. of Sulphur) with mid-day and mid-night aggravation and has fear of death.The burning of Phosphorus is found in every organ, e.g. in internal organs, in spots,along spine, in the palms, and soles; but generally in diseases of nervous system,which is worst in the evening.

6. A weak empty all-gone sensation in the stomach (Sepia, Chelidonium, Pulsatilla, Anacardium), especially about 11 a.m. (12 noon, Zincum met.).    Cannotwait for lunch.


7. Congestion in single parts; eyes, nose, lips, anus, etc. g. Sulphur should be thought of in the first instance when the patient comes with a history of suppression of skin diseases by external apptication e.g., lotions,ointments, etc.

9. There is intense craving for sweet, acid, alcohol, beer, whisky, aversion to milk, meat and business.

10. All the discharges, e.g. leucorrhoea, nasal discharge, etc. are ACRID AND OFFENSIVE.

11. Aggravation by heat is another keynote of Sulphur, especially by warmth of bed.

12. Sulphur facilitates absorption of serous or inflammatory exudates in pleura, joints, when the best selected remedies like—Apis, Bryonia, etc. fail.

13. Mind : Ragged philosopher. Even rags seem beautiful when the patient takes a fancy for it. Everything seems full of beauty. He dresses himself in the most filthyrags but considers tfiem to be the most elegant of decorations. The patient wears a paper crown, thinking he is His Majesty, the king. There is great weakness of memory. Cannot find the proper word during conversation. He is very selfish and has no regard for others. Sulphur is indifferentand disinclined to work of any and every description. Nothing appeals to him. Work,pleasure, talking, exercise, etc. afford him no enjoyment.There is a feeling of movement in abdomen, as of a child (Crocus, Thuja). Happy dreams wake him up singing at night. He is of a nervous temperament and hypochondriacal in nature.

14, Ailments from : Alcohol, suppression of skin diseases, Sun’s heat, over exertion, etc.

PARTICULARS

Gastro-intestinal system :

Abdomen : There is WEAK, EMPTY, ALL GONE OR FAINT FEELING IN THE ABDOMEN AT ABOUT 11 A.M. Cannot wait for lunch. Frequent, weak, faint spells during the day with buming sensation.

There is great desire for sweets.


Aggravation from milk and meat.

Movement in the abdomen as of a foetus, is felt by the patient.

© Causation: Alcoholism and suppression of skin eruption.

© Causation: Suppression of skin disease’s and alcoholism.

* Aggravation in early morning.

© Concomitants: Diarrhoea alternates with constipation, Respiratory symptoms.

Causation: Due to suppression of skin diseases.

Stage: In delayed resolution.

Location: Usually upper left lobe of the: lung is affected.

Female genital organs :

Skin :

Sulphur is indicated in all sorts of skin eruptions, vesicular, pustular, etc., especially in the skin

There is severe itching, voluptuous itching;goes on scratching. It feels good to scratch, but scratching is followed by severe burning, rawnessand soreness of the parts.

The babies are prone to have worm infestations with intense CRAVING FOR SWEETS.

The child cries before stool.

chapter 199 :  SYPHILINUM

Syphilitic discharge SWAN A Nosode

INTRODUCTION

This great nosode of historical importance, has been introduced into the Homoeopathic MateriaMedica by Dr. Swan. He prepared it from thesyphilitic discharges and used it in the treatmentof syphilitic patients. He has., of course, done itempirically after potentising accordingto theDoctrine of Dynamisation. At present, it. holds theplace of the “KING OF ANTI-SYPHILITICS”amongst the nosodes so far proved. Dr. Hering remarks, “No patient having syphilitic history in the past can be declaredcured until and unless this nosode is administered at least once in the course of thetreatment. So much is its importance if adequately given”.

CLINICAL

Abscess, Alcoholism, Asthma, Boils, Constipation, Deltoid rheumatism, Dentitipn, Diplopig, Heart troubles, Headache, Leucorrhoea, Neuralgia, Ozoena, Prtosis,Rheumatism, Sciatica, Syphilis, Ulcers, etc.

SPHERES OF ACTION

It acts chiefly on the brain and spinal cord. Bones, periosteum, skin and mucous membrane also come under the spheres of action of this drug.

PATHOGENESIS

Its action results in manifestation of various stages of syphilis in different organs, nervous symptoms, brain and heart.

CONSTITUTION

Physical make-up: Many different types of eruptions; particularly copper coloured, which become blue on getting cold.

Temperament: Melancholic temperament.

Miasm: Syphilis is in the background.

GUIDING SYMPTOMS

1. Whenever there is a history of syphilis in the patient or in the family, we should think of Syphilinum.

2. All the symptoms are WORSE AT NIGHT (MERC.), FROM SUNSET TO SUNRISE.

3. When the best selected remedy fails to relieve or permanently improve especially in syphilitic affections.

. Pain from sunset to sunrise, pain increases and decreases gradually, shifting in nature. Requires frequent changes of position.

. Leucorrhoca is profuse, soaking through the napkin and running down the heels; worse at night.

. Craving for ALCOHOL IN ANY FORM. Hereditary tendency to alcoholism.

. Ptosis, paralysis of superior oblique muscles of the eye, sleepy look from drooping lids.

. Teeth decay at edges of gums and break off; edges are serrated; dwarfed in size,

converge at their tips.

. Obstinate constipation for years; rectum seems tied up with stricture.

Rheumatism of trie shoulder joint or at insertion of deltoid.

Mind : Loss of memory. Loses remembrance of present occurrences Cannot recollect the names, dates, persons, places, etc. Arithmetical calculations are verydifficult. Sensation as if going to be insane; as if about to be paralysed, apathy andindifference, Terrible dread of night on account of the mental and physicalexhaustion on awaking. It is intolerable and death is preferable. Fears the terrificsuffering from exhausting on awaki:g.

12. Ailments from : Syphilis.

PARTICULARS

Eye:

In ophthalmia neonatorum, chronic and recurrent phlyctenular inflammation of cornea, this remedy is indicated as follows:

Location: Especially in the left eye. Successive crops of phlyctenule and abrasion of epithelial layer of cornea.

Character of pain: There is intense sharp, pulsating pain with intense photophobia. Lids are

swollen and adhere during sleep. Furthermore, there is ptosis consequent upon paralyisis of superior oblique muscle of the eye. Sleepy look from drooping lids. Diplopia, one image seen below the other.

Modalities:
 Aggravation: From 2 to 5 a.m., at night.

 Amelioration: By cold application.

Headache :

Causation: Sunstroke, excitement and syphilis.

Location: Across the temple.

Sensation: As if head would be crushed, with sense of weight and bursting in the vertex.

Character of pain: Neuralgic pain, intolerable pain. Violent pain in the whole head with red face,

enlarged veins of the face, restless and sleepless night. Lancinating pain in the eyes. Pain increases and decreases gradually. Pains frequently shifting place with change of position.

Modality: Aggravation at night, from dusk to daylight, from heat of sun, from 10-11 p.m.

Mouth :

Causation: Syphilitic and fungal infection of mouth.

Sensation: Mouth feels as if ulcerated and burns like FIRE. Tongue coated white; edges indented by teeth. Two deep cracks, running lengthwise on it; one on either side of the median line. Ulceration of thetongue, lips, buccal cavity and fauces which smart and burn like fire.

Character of pain: Smarting pain in the mouth. Teeth decay at edges of the gum and break off; edges serrated and dwarfed in size with convergent tips. Excessive flow of saliva.

Modality: Aggravation: At night and from mastication.

Constipation :

Causation: Syphilitic affection.

Sensation: As if the rectum is tied’up with strictures.

Character: Obstinate constipation for years. Rectum seems to be tied up with strictures, when enema was used the agony of passage was like that of labour. Chronic constipation with foetid breath.Stool is light or dark coloured and very offensive. Character of the pain is like that of labour.

Modality: Aggravation by passing stool.

Heart :

Lancinating pain in the heart at night, from base to apex. Better at high altitude and aggravation at sea shore and at night (Pain from apex to base, Med.; from base to shoulder, Spigelia).

Leucorrhoea :

Yellow offensive leucorrhoea, very muh offensive and profuse. It daily soaks through napkin with pain across the small of the back.

Bones :
Causation: Syphilitic affection.

Location : Especially in long bones of upper and lower extremities.

Inflammation of all joints; rheumatism. Pain and swelling in limbs with stiffness. Severe pain in long bones, particularly extremities preventing sleep. Caries of cervical and dorsal vertebrae.

Character of pain: Severe, lancinating pain from sunset to sunrise. Pain comes gradually and goes
away slowly.

Modalities:
Aggravation: From hot application; warmth of bed; at night and extremes of heat and cold.

Amelioration: From pouring cold water on affected parts, from walking and at daybreak.

General Modalities :

Aggravation: At night, from twilight to daylight and at sea shore.

Amelioration: At high altitude.

Relations :

Compare: Aurum, Mercurius and Phytolacca in syphilitic affections.

chapter :201 TABACUM

Tobacco Solanaceae

INTRODUCTION

The symptoms of the pathogenesis are composed partly of provings made by LembkeSchreter and others and partly of poisonings andoverdosings.

CLINICAL

Amaurosis, Angina  Pectoris. Asthma. Backache. Cholera. Constipation. Diarrhoea.Headache. Hiccough. Pregnancy sickness. Renalcolic. Sea sickness. Vertigo etc. Hypertension.Heart-dilatation of.

SPHERES OF ACTION

It has profound, action on nerves espe-cially Vagi and Heart. It also acts on eyes, G.I. Tract, and urinary system.

PATHOGENESIS

It causes cerebal irritation followed by marked irritation of functions of Vagi. It produces muscular prostration, free secretions. It produces (brings forth) symptoms,which are experienced by people who had taken tobacco first time in their lives such asnausea, vomiting, salivation, giddiness even one may faint with prostation and coldsweating.

CONSTITUTION

Make-up : Patient is emaciated, pale, blue, sunken, Emaciation of cheeks and back. Sometimes deathly pallorness covered with cold sweat.

Heat cold relation : Hot patient.

Miasm : All the 3 miasms are in the background but it is chiefly an antipsoric Temedy.

GUIDING SYMPTOMS :

1) Deathly nausea, vomiting, and giddiness with death like pallor.

2) Vertigo on opening the eyes (on closing the eyes—Lach., Thuja., Theri.)

3) Icy coldness of surface; covered with cold sweat.

4) A weak, faint sinking feeling at pit of stomach.

5) Child wants abdomen uncovered which relieves nausea & vomiting.

6) Sea sickness—Aggravated by least motion and relieved on deck in fresh cold air Car Sickness—Coccul., Petrol. Air Sickness—Bell., Mountain    Sickness—Coca, Home Sickness—Caps.

7) Sensation of excessive wretchedness and great despon-dency.

8) Symptoms occur in paroxysms such as asthma, sick headache, vertigo, sneezing.

9) Palpitation violent when lying on left side and goes off when turning to the right.

10) Many symptoms are aggravated on least motion (compare Ipe., Bry., Lob. In.)

11) Ailments from—abuse of tobacco, masturbation, at sea, shock, violent physical exertion.

PARTICULARS

Headache

It is needed in periodical sick headache which begins in the morning increases during day and last of until evening (Sang C., Spig. Nat M, Nat Carb. etc.) and lastig one or two days.

Location : Whole head especially right side.

Sensation : Pain as if struck by a hammer or club. Tight feeling as from band (Gels., Spig. etc.)

Modalities : Aggravation—by noise light, motion.

Amelioration : in open fresh air.

Concomitant : Deathly nausea and vomiting. There may be vertigo on opening the eyes.

Vertigo

Vertigo on opening the eyes is a strong feature of this remedy. It increases loss of consciousness with death like pallor. Vertigo on rising or looking upward and is relieved in open fresh air and by vomiting.

Eyes

It has a good action over the eyes. Dim sighted—Sees as through a veil.

Amaurosis—From atrophy of retina or optic nerve. Fre-quent recurrence of amblyopia. It is also to be thought of in stravismus when depending upon brain troubles. Heart

It has been recommended in dilatation of the heart caused by a shock or violent physical exertion and in angina with high tension,

Sensation : Constriction of throat and tightness feeling across the upper part of the chest.

Pain :Pain in praecordial region. Pain radiates from centre of sternum.

Pulse :Feeble, imperceptible and intermittent.

Modality : Aggravation on least motion, indoor (in warm room) relieved in open fresh cold air, uncovering.



Concomitant—There is paroxysmal oppression, tinnitus aurium, muscae volitantes with violent palpitation when lying on left side and pallor of skin. Mind calm and no fear of death.

Sweat—Cold clammy sweating with coldness of body.

Gastro-intestinal tract:

Stomach :

Causation—tobacco, going at sea, during cholera.


Sensation : There is terrible, faint, sinking feeling at pit of stomach and sensation of hanging or relaxation of stomach with incessant nausea and vomiting (Ipecac)

Nausea : With faintness; worse smell of tobacco smoke and better in open air. Vomiting with cold sweat and worse on least motion. It is also useful in vomiting during pregnancy with much _ spitting.

Abdomen : Patient wants abdomen uncovered which relieves nausea and vomiting. Coldness in abdomen (Colch., Lach.)

Rectum : Constipation—Chronic constipation of years standing due to inactivity of bowel or paralysis of rectum, spasm of anal sphincter.

Diarrhoea : Sudden with nausea, vomiting, prostration, cold sweat and extreme fainting from smell of tobacco. Stool is yellowish, greenish, slimy, watery sometimes may look like sour milk.

Urinary : Renal colic with violent spasmodic pains along left ureter accompanied by deathly nausea and cold perspiration. (Right Ureteric Colic-Ocimum Can.)

General modalities :

Aggravation : from motion, from lying on left side, from heat, in warm room, extremes of heat and cold.

Amelioration : Open fresh cold air, uncovering, from cold application.

Relations

Antidotes for abuse of tobacco are —

For ailments from tobacco chewing—Arsenic
For hiccough from tobacco chewing—Ignatia
For excessive nauses & vomiting—Ipecac.
For occipital headache and vertigo from excessive smoking—Gelsemium.
For importency caused by tobacco smoking—Lycopodium.
For gastric symptoms next morning after smoking—Nux Vomica.
For palpitation, tobacco heart & sexual weakness—Phosphorus.
For tobacco dyspepsia, neuralgia & chronic nervousness— Sepia.
For tobacco toothache—Clematis & Plantago Major,
For cough excited by tobacco smoke—Staphy. & Spongia.
N.B.: Caladium and Plantago Major destroy craving for tobacco. Tabacum also relieves terrible Craving when use is discontinued.

Antidoted by : Vinegar, sour apples, Camphor,

Antidotes : Bad effects of Cicuta Virosa.

chapter :203 TARENTULA CUBENSIS

Cuban Spider Aranaediceae

INTRODUCTION

Though it is not a polychrest medicine as it has limited sphere of action, still it has got thepower to make Surgeon’s knife useless andrelieves the most serious cases of blood boils,carbuncle, felons and gangrene etc. In Allen’sKeynote Tarentula Hispania & Tarentula cubensis both are given under one heading“Tarantula” though they are different medicines. Tarentula cubensis is a largerspider of a dark brown colourless poisonousvariety & covered with more hair than theTarentula Hispania. Tarentula Cubensis is prepared from the whole hairy spider. This spider is very
poisonous.

Clinical

Anthrax. Abscess. Carbuncle. Fever. Felon. Gangrene. Septic Fever. Ulcer etc.

Tarentula cubensis is a medicine for above mentioned dis-eases when there is severe type inflammations and septic conditions and even malignancy, if the following symptoms are present.

1) Atrocious burning pains, stinging pains, make the patient restless and compels him to walk at night. It is the remedy for pains of death.

3) Very early & persistent prostration.

4) Intermittent septic chills.

5) Hyperaesthesia relieved by constant movement & some kind of friction.

6) Modalities :

Aggravation—at night, contact, touch of affected parts

Amelioration—Rubbing affected parts,

Dr. Benthack says Tarentula Cubensis and Arsenicum Alb, are complementary to ach other in septic inflammatory states,

chapter : 208 THUJA OCCIDENTALIS

Arbor Vitae

White cedar HAHNEMANN 

Tree of life

INTRODUCTION

Thuja IS ONE OF HAHNEMANN’S GREATEST DISCOVERIES. Most of themedicines of his Materia Medica had been in vogue as therapeutic tools beforehis time. Of the therapeutic properties ofThuja, practically nothing was known until Hahnemann proved it. Subsequenobservers have only confirmed thepathogenesis proved and established byHahnemann. He specified it as “THEONLY EFFICACIOUS REMEDY FORFIG WARTS AND GONORRHOEA”. Hahnemann found in Thuja the antidote to the miasmatic condition which he termed. SYCOSIS, meaning thereby the constitutional } wor disease resulting from gonorrhoea and having its characteristic manifestations, viz.> ah excrescences in the form of warts, sometimes dry, more frequently soft and spongy, emitting a foetid fluid having a sweetish odour, bleeding readily and having acauliflower-like from.

CLINICAL

Abdomen distended, Abortion, Angina pectoris, Asthma, Cancer, Chorea, Condylomata, Constipation, Convulsion, Diarrhoea, Epilepsy, Eye affection, Gleet,Gonorrhoea, Haemorrhoids, Headache, Polypus, Prostatic disorders, Rheumatism, Tea—bad effects of, Teeth affection, Urinary affection, Vaccination, Warts, Whooping cough, ete.

SPHERES OF ACTION

Thuja acts on skin and genito-urinary organs. It has also got action on the nervous system, especially the brain, gastrointestinal tract, etc.


PATHOGENESIS

As far as the pathogenesis of the drug is concerned, HERING states that it has too many characteristic actions.

On the fluids: “Dissolution of fluids of the body, which become acrid, probably caused by Thuja which perverts lymphatic secretions; disturbs digestion and sanguinification.”

In the vegetative sphere: A surplus of life producing matter undergoes nearly unlimited proliferation in the shape of pathological vegetations, in the shape of


condylomata, warts, sycotic excrescences, spongy tumours and spongy pock exudates which organise hastily. All morbid manifestations are excessive, but appear quietly 39that the beginning of the diseased state is scarcely.known. Extra unwanted growths, bywhatever name it may be called, in any and every tissue of the body, are caused by thisgreat “KING OF ANTI-SYCOTIC DRUGS, THUJA”.

CONSTITUTION

Physical make-up: Hydrogenoid constitution of Grauvogl (Antim. tart., Natrum. sulph., Medorrhinurn).Thuja is suited to patient having hydrogenoid constitution(possessing an increased capacity to contain more and more water in the cytoplasm of thecells; hence rain, cold, damp weather, vegetable food, etc., which increases the number ofmolecules of water in the system, aggravate the symptoms). The patients are fleshyhaving undue and unwanted growths, such as warts, tumours, cysts, etc., having darkhair and dark complexion; unhealthy, oily, greasy skin, bearing warty excrescences anddirty brownish white spots all over the body.

According to Dr. B.K. Bose of Calcutta, Thuja patients, look like “GANESJI”, with distended abdomen and bulky body, having-lavish growth of various tissues everywhere.

Temperament: Lymphatic temperament; sluggish in action and perception. Relation with heat and cold: Chilly patient (Boericke).

Miasm: Sycosis is in the background. Thuja is the king of anti-sycotic remedies.

THYROIDINUM

Dried thyroid gland of Sheep or calf (A Sarcode)

INTRODUCTION

This remedy may be prepared either from the dried triturated thyroid gland ofthe sheep or calf or from extract made fromit. To be able to arrive at a proper under-standing of its symptomatology one shouldconsider the physiology of the gland. Theadministration of thyroid gland in largedoses acclerates protein and fat metabolismand causes increased elimination ofnitrogen, phosphorus, chlorine etc.Clinically polyuria, sweating, tachycardia,tre-mor, emaciation and glycosuria are observed. The removal of the thyroid glandon the other hand leads to anaemia, oligaemia, myxoedema, cretinism and obesity.

CLINICAL

Albuminuria, Amenorrhoea. Anaemia. Convul-sion. Cretinism. Dropsy. Eczema. Fractures. Goitre, Milk deficiency, Hysteroepilepsy. Myxaedema. Obesity. Psoriasis. Headache. Enuresis. Rheumatic Arthritis. Undesce’nded testicle.

Thyroidinum acts upon glandular system especially thyroid gland, female genitalia, skin, nerves, blood, bones etc. 

GUIDING SYMPTOMS

1) It is suited to thin or obese persons with an irregular deposition of fat, but are usually pale and anaemic. There may be exophthalmic look.

2) Chilly patient. There is sensation of chilliness with increased sensitivity to cold and aggravation from cold.

3) A state of puffiness and obesity may be regarded as a keynote indication for Thyrodinum—clarke.

4) Tachycardia.

5) Palpitation : From least exertion (Calc. Ars.)

6) Excessive sweating.

7) Craving for sweet.

8) Thirst for cold water.

10) Coldness and tingling in extremeties.

11) Poly urea : Urine contains some albumen and sugar.

12) Persistent frontal headache.

18) Nausea : Worse riding in car with much flatulency.

14) Mentally patient is highly irritable. Can’t bear least opposition and goes into passions about trifles. Depres-sion. Stupour alternates with     restless melancholia. Attimes becomes homicidal patient want to strangle every body by putting his armsvery tightly round their necks.

15) It is said to be useful in undescended testicles in boys.

16) It is indicated in deficient milk secretion specially when associated with return of menses.

PARTICULARS

Head

Persistent frontal headache. Feeling of lightness in brain. Eyeballs prominent. Fullness & heat in head with flushed face.

Eyes

Prominent Eyeballs. Progressive diminution of sight with central scotoma.

Stomach

Desire for sweets and thirst. for cold water. Nausea worse riding in car. Flatulence, much flatus in abdomen.

Dry, painful cough with scanty, difficult expectoration and burning in pharynx.

Urinary symptoms

Polyuria with increased flow, some albumen and sugar. Urine smells of violets, burning along urethra, increase of uric acid. Enuresis in weakly children who are nervous and irritable.

Heart

Weak, frequent pulse, with inability to lie down. Tachycardia. Palpitation from least exertion. Ready excitability of heart. Severe heart pain.

CLINICAL

.As far as the curative value of this drug is concerned, it can be given in all cases of variola—whether single, confluent, haemorrhagic or     malignant and in varioloid and vericella, if and when they appear even after vaccination is given.But as a preventive against smallpox as well as a protection against it, this remedy is far superior to crude vaccination and is absolutely safe and free from any sequelae especially of septic and tubercular infection.

. It protects from, modifies and cures smallpox.

. It is also most efficacious, infallible and suitable in smallpox both for curative and preventive purposes in any potency—low or high.

chapter : 216 VERATRUM ALBUM

White Hellebore HAHNEMANN Melanthaceale

INTRODUCTION

White Hellebore, as it is commonly called, was known for centuries as one of the great remedies for collaspe and pain. Hahnemann’s provings established this fact by testing its reaction on the healthy provers. He tells.us in his Materia Medica  Pura some revealing things about this drug, particularly about its mental sphere which are as follows - “Physicians have no notion of the power possessed by this drug to promote a cure of almost one-third of the insane in lunatic asylums because they know not the pecular kind of insanity in which to employ it, nor the dose in which it should be administered in order to be efficacious and yet not injurious.

CLINICAL

Angina pectoris, Apoplexy, Asthma, Cholera, Colic, Collaspe, Constipation, Cramps, Debility, Diarrhoea, Epilepsy, Gastric and abdominal disorders, Headache, Influenza, Intermittent fever, Labour, Mania, Melancholia, Meningitis, Menstrual disorders, Rheumatism, Vertigo, etc.

SPHERES OF ACTION

Veratrum album acts especially upon the system of nutrition affecting profoundly the vegetative sphere. It also acts upon the blood and nervous system.

PATHOGENESIS

It causes disorganisation of blood and seperates it into its constitutent components. The circulation becomes embarassed and as a result, there is general torpor of the vegetative system. It gives rise to choleric condition, general coldness, prostration, collaspe, copious watery vomiting and purging, spasmodic colic, cramps and spasms. Its action on the nervous system results in excitation of the cerebral nerves producing
thereby delirum and mania, in addition to great exhaustion of nerve power.

CONSTITUTION

As it is mainly an acute remedy, no importane is to be attached to be physical make-up or constitution as such of the patient. But it is especially suited to the complaints of People too young and too old (i.e. extremes of age)

Temperament: Nervous and sanguine temperament.

Relation with heat and cold: Chilly patient.

Miasm: Psora is in the background.

GUIDING SYMPTOMS

1.“Profuseness” of all discharges is the key-note symptom of this drug. This criterion runs through the whole remedy, e.g., in diarrhoea,    vomiting, sweat, etc.
2. Rapid sinking of the Vital Force; complete prostration and collapsed condition.
3. Craving for acids, refreshing things, fruits, cold food, water and juicy things (Phos.). Aversion to warm things.
4. Cold perspiration all over the body especially on the forehead; with nearly all complaints.
5. Violent vomiting with profuse diarrhoea.
6. Bad effects of fright, opium taking, tobacco chewing, etc.
7. Intense unquenchable thirst for large quantities of cold water; wants everything cold. N.B. Profuse cold perspiration on forehead, extreme coldness, blueness and weakness are manifested by this drug with nearly all complaints.

8. Mind : The mental symptoms of Veratrum album are much more important for arriving at a proper selection of the remedy than its other symptoms.

It has got all THREE TYPES OF MANIA i.e., the violent mania of Belladonna, the religious mania of Stramonium and the lascivious mania of Hyoscyamus and each one of them tries to supersede the other.

Sometimes the patient becomes VIOLENT AND DESTRUCTIVE. He wants to destroy, to tear something, he tears the clothes, due to violent cerebral congestion. There is bloated face and a disposition to bite and tear. This is only one phase of the mania.

In the other phase of the mania the patient becomes very much lascivious. Sings obscene songs, thinks lewd thoughts, exhibits immodesty; the patient does not want to cover his privateparts, kicks off the clothes and lies naked on the bed and exposes
the person. There is maniacal desire to kiss everyboy—NYMPHOMANIA AND SATYRIASIS.

In the third phase there is the RELIGIOUS MANIA. The patient talks all the time about God. There is a state of religious frenzy. He is praying and beseeching all the time without respite.

Whenever we find all these three types of mania in a patient and when all these mainas compete to supersede one another, Veratrum album is the
only remedy to be thought of and administered.



There is yet another state of mind also found in Veratrum album i.e., a state of brooding, full of despair and hopelessness. The patient is melancholic, sits and broods in silence.

The patient does not want to be alone, yet persistently refuses to talk. Sensation of a lump of ice on the vertex.
Thinks that she is pregnant and will soon be delivered. Cholera like symptoms after fright is also covered by this drug.

Ailments from : Fright, shock, injury, disappointed love, suppressed exanthema,opium, tobacco, alcohol and fruits.

PARTICULARS

Gastro-intestinal symptoms :

The usual complaints met with in this drug, relating to the gastrointestinal tract, are VIOLENT DIARRHOEA AND VOMITING OR CONSTIPATION. Violence in everything is the striking peculiarity of this remedy.

There is great thirst for huge.quanitity of icy cold-water.

cramps: With cholera there are cramps which commence in hands and feet and spread all over the body.

In short—extreme coldness, blueness, weakness arid excessiveness of all the discharges, make one to think of Veratrum album, in cholera.

Veratum album differs from CAMPHOR in cholera. There is “DRY CHOLERA” with coldness, blueness, scanty sweat, vomiting and purging in Camphor. chapter :217 VERATRUM VIRIDE

Green Hellebore BURT Melanthaceae

INTRODUCTION

Veratrum viride is a small but powerful drug. It is mostly used in severe acute cases, such as severe form of headache, sunstroke, basilar
meningitis, convulsion, acute rheumatism, etc. It has direct action over heart, causing depression
of heartbeat and low pulse rate. So never misuse it and never repeat it very frequently just to
control the heart’s action or bring down thepulse. Like any other remedy it can only be given for the totality of symptoms.
Hale was chifly instrumental in introducing Veratrum viride into Homoeopathy, using it particularly in pneumonia.

Belladonna has got muchsimilarity with Veratrum viride. So, never substitute it when Veratrum viride is indicated. Individual and comparative study of these two drugs are necessary for a correct prescription.

CLINICAL
Apoplexy, Asthma, Brain affection, Chorea, Convulsion, Erysipelas, Headache, Heart affection, Hyperpyrexia, Fever, Meningitis, Pneumonia, Rheumatism, Sunstroke, etc.

SPHERES OF ACTION

Veraturm viride acts on heart, blood vessels, pneumo-gastric nerve, lungs and joints. It particularly acts on the cervical portion of spinal cord and the base of the brain.

PATHOGENESIS

Acting on the heart, it lowers both systolic and diastolic blood pressure. It also on the internal organs such as the base of brain, chest, spine, stomach, etc. and produces congestion.

CONSTITUTION

Since Veratrum viride is mostly an acute drug, consideration of constitution is not of much importance. The patient is however, full blooded, plethoric, with bloated and livid face.

GUIDING SYMPTOMS

1. A narrow, well developed red streak right through the middle of the toungue, is the red-strand symptom of this drug.
2. Sudden onset of all the troubles as in Aconite and Belladonna, is a great indicator of Veratrum viride.
3. Congestion is yet another leading keynote of Veraturm viride, especially congestion in the base of brain, spine, lung and stomach.
4. Sensation of fulness in the head causing a heavy headache.
5.Pulse Suddenly increases and gradually decreases below normal; slow, soft, weak, irregular and intermittent pulse (Digitalis); low tension.
6. Beating of pulse throughout the body, especially in the right thigh.
7. Everything tastes sweet.
8. Ailments from : Going into sun’s rays, going from hot to-cold, after suppression of menses and lochia.

PARTICULARS

Meningitis :
Causation: Meningitis may be caused by exposure to heat.

Onset: Sudden and violent.

Character: Basiter meningitis; convulsion, dim vision, RETRACTED, PUPILS DILATED, tetanic

convulsion, cold and clammy perspiration. Pain in the nape of neck, cannot hold the head up; opisthotonos.

Modalities:
 Aggravation: By motion, raising the head, exposure to heat and cold and sitting erect.

 Amelioration: By remaining quiet, lying down and rubbing.

Apoplexy :

Congestive apoplexy, head hot; blood-shot eyes, thick speech, pulse full and hard as iron. Bloated livid face. Hippocratic face, with red streak down the middle of the tongue.

Sunstroke :
Face is flushed; head full; throbbing of arteries, bearing of pulse throughout the body; vertigo with nausea. Convulsive twitching of the faeial muscles. Sensitive to sound; double vision or partial vision (Glon., Gels).

Headache :

Causation: Exposure to sun’s rays, heat and extreme cold, suppression of menses and lochia.

Onset; Sudden and violent Onset.

Character: Violent nerypus sick headache: Congestion from suppressed menses. Intense, almost
apopletic headache; throbbini of arteries; head hot and face flushed


Modalities:

Aggravation: By motion, raising the head, warmth.

Amelioration: By remaining quiet, lying down and tigh  bandaging.

Concomitants:; Nausea and vomiting, with blood-shot eyes.

Blood pressure :

Veratrum viride is a very good medicine for high blood pressure whenever symptoms correspond i.e.its peculiar pulse, characteristic tongue and face, throbbibng of carotids, BLOOD SHOT EYES AND HEAD, etc. point to this drug.

Tongue :

The key-note of Veratrum viride is its peculiar and most characteristic tongue. The tongue is white or yellow, but with RED STREAK DOWN THE MIDDLE. Tongue may be, dry, moist, with white or yellow coating or no coating on either side, feels scalded (Sanguinaria) with increased saliva.

Pneumonia :

Causation: Exposure to cold or heat and sun’s rays.

Mode of Onset: Sudden and violent onset

Stage: Veratrum viride is indicated in the congestive stage or early stage and hepatisation stage of pneumnonia.

Character: There is difficult breathing. Sensation of a heavy load on chest, Paint feeling in STOMACH.

INTRODUCTION

The relief of human suffering is a noble cause. Those who devote their life in this cause truly deserves the gratitude of their fellows. In the history of the healing art, onesuch name is Wilhelm Heinrich Schuessler, one of the outstanding intellects of theninentinth century and a man whose scientific vision was far ahead of his time. Dr.Schuessler was not only a doctor of medicine, but he was also a physiological chemist anda physicist. His keen, analytical mind was able to assimilate and to co-ordinate the far-reaching physiological discoveries of great contemporary scientists. As a practisingphysician, he was able to put his carefully worked-out theories to the test and thebrilliant results he achieved led to the formulation of his unique system of cellulartherapeutics, to which he gave the name - Biochemistry/Biochemic System of Medicne.Thus Dr. Wilhelm Heinrich Schuessler is considered as the founder of the BiochemicSystem of Medicine.

DR. WILHELM HEINRICH SCHUESSLER

Dr. Wilhelm Heinrich Schuessler was born on the 21st of August 1821 in Oldenburg, Germany. Sincechildhood, Schuessler was a studious boy and hadremarkable capabilities. He devoted most of his timelearning foreign languages like Latin, Greek, Spanish,French, English and Italian. He wanted to become aHomeopathic physician when he grew up, but his brothertold him that he would assist him to become one, only ifhe became a legally qualified practitioner. Keeping to hisword, Schuessler studied medicine at the University ofBerlin, Paris, Geissen and Prague. He then qualified as a

homeopathic practitioner and started his practice at
: 21st August, 1821 Oldenburg.

30th March, 1898 Dr. Schuessler was very much influenced by Rudolph Virchow (the founder of cellular pathology), who taught that all diseases are based on a change in the function ofcells in the body. Another important person who influenced him greatly was ProfessorMoleschott, who pointed out that the structure and vitality of the organs depends uponthe presence of inorganic constituents. Based on the theories of these two, Schuesslerformulated his own doctrine, which he called the Cell salt therapy or the Biochemicsystem of medicine. He is also referred as the Father of deficiency therapy. Dr Schuessler believed that when a human being is reduced to ashes by heat, thereare only twelve minerals left, These he called as the tissue salts. They are responsiblefor the natural balance and vitality of the body. According to him, deficiency of any ofthese tissue salts produces a diseased condition in the human organism, andreplenishment or supplementation of the body by the deficient salt, in physiological dosesrestores health in the organism. Schuessler potentised these tissue salts and made theminto biochemic remedies,

Schuessler wrote a lot of books during his time. In 1878, he published his first article on his healing system in the General homeopathic Journal, and titled it ‘An AbridgedTherapy based on physiology and cellular pathology’.

He had lot of ardent followers like Elizabeth Hubbard, Dr Stephenson, Dr. MBlackmore and others. In 1958, Dr Blackmore popularized Schuessler’s works in his book- ‘Colloids- A textbook for physicians’ He also refined Schuessler’s salts by addingmore tissue salts besides the existing twelve (except for sodium chloride).

The most interesting account of the application of Schuesslers’ remedies is to befound in the book titled “Nature’s 12 Magic Healers: The Amazing Secrets of Cell Salts”by Lionel Rolfe and Nigey Lennon. This book contains comments on the value of thesesalts by two eminent homeopathic physicians, Dr. J. H. Renner MD and Dr. William E.S. Jackson MD. Schuessler died in the year 1898, but his works have remained immortal.

HISTORY OF THE TISSUE REMEDIES

Samuel Hahnemann was the first to establish the great importance of the inorganic cell salts as medicines of a high order thorough investigation into their pathogeneticeffects and therapeutic uses. It was his provings of Lime, Salt, Potash and Silicia thatshowed what vast store-houses of medicinal force these inorganic substances are,although wholly inert in their crude state. This prepared the way for the development ofthe rest of the Tissue Remedies. He was the first who pointed out how these forces couldbe unlocked and directed for therapeutic purposes.

Later, in 1832, attention was called in a paper published in Stapfs Archiv to the great importance as remedies of all the “ essential component parts of the human body,” and again, in the same Journal, in 1846; “All constituents of the human body principally act on those organs wherein they have a function. All fulfill their functions when they are the cause of symptoms.” This comes from the pen of that remarkable genius in the field of Materia Medica — Constantine Hering.

Later on, Grauvogl, in his Text-Book, taking some notice of these remarks, amplified them. But it remained for Dr. Schiissler, of Oldenburg, Germany, to develop these suggestions and make the idea foreshadowed in them the basis of a “new system.” In March, 1873, an article, entitled “ Abridged Homoeopathic Therapeutics” from his pen, was published in a Gennan Homceopathic journal, in which he says : “About a year ago I
endeavored to discover by experiments on the sick if it were not possible to heal them, provided their diseases were curable at all, with those substances that are the natural, ie., the physiological function-remedies,” Of this no special notice seems to have been
taken, until, five months subsequently, Dr. Lorbacher, of Leipzig, came out in the same journal with some critical considerations of it. This was followed by a reply from Schussler, which ran through seven numbers, giving a more detailed account of this
“Abridged System of Homoeopathic Therapeutics,” the important features of which are incorporated in this work.

The original communication from Schussler to the German journal was translated into English, and published first in the Medical Investigator, May, 1873, and soon afterwards in a small work, by Dr. C. Hering, entitled the “ Twelve Tissue Remedies,”


Biochemic System of Medicine 659
“recommended for investigation” by this great teacher of our school. Several editions were published in rapid succession, from which this historical sketch is mainly derived, and following these appeared the translation of the twelfth German edition, by J. T. o’Connor, M. D,, and one by M. Docetti Walker, considerably enlarged by the addition of an appendix popularizing the Biochemic Method. Dr. Schussler, previous io his death, which occurred early in 1898, published the 25th German edition, in which the application of several of the remedies has been greatly enlarged and considerable new matter added. This edition has just been translated into English.

Notwithstanding that Dr. Schussler denies in the later editions of his work all connection with Homoeopathy, and insists that his method is not based upon the homoeopathic law of cure, but upon physiologico-chemical processes that take place within the organism, it is nevertheless true that the present wide adoption of the Tissue Remedies in the treatment of disease is the fruit of the seed sown on homoepathic ground
as early as 1832, although its development was slow until Schussler gave it a wonderful impetus by bringing physiological chemistry and physiological and petdlacibel facts to bear on his therapeutic procedure

THE THEORY OF SCHUSSLER’S BIOCHEMIC SYSTEM OF MEDICINE

The idea upon which Biochemic Therapeutics is based is the physiological fact that both the structure and vitality of the organs of the body are dependent upon certain necessary quantities and proper apportionment of its inorganic constituents. These remain after combustion of the tissues and form the ashes.

These inorganic constituents are, in a very real sense, the material basis of the organs and tissues of the body, and are absolutely essential to their integrity of structure and functional activity. According to Schussler’s theory, any disturbance in the molecular motion of these cell salts in living tissues, caused by a deficiency in the requisite amount, constitutes disease, which can be rectified and the requisite equilibrium re-established by administering the same minezal salts in small quantities. This is supposed to be brought about by virtue of the operation of chemical affinity in the domain of histology ; and hence this therapeutic procedure is styled by Schussler the Biochemic method, and stress is laid on the fact that it is in supposed harmony with well-known facts and laws in physiological chemistry and allied sciences.

FOUNDATION OF BIOCHEMIC SYSTEM OF MEDICINE

The foundation of Biochemistry was laid more than a century ago when Rudolph Virchow, one of the foremost scientists of the day, discovered that the human body is composed of an enormous number of tiny, living cells, each one made up of an infinitesimal but perfectly balanced quantity of three classes of materials; water, organic Substances, inorganic substances,

Water and organic matter, such as sugar, albuminous and fatty substances make up the greater portion of the body. The inorganic (mineral) elements, however, although present invery much smaller quantities, are really vital elements; active workers which utilise theorganic substances in building the millions of cells of which the body is composed.


The life of these cells is of short duration. Millions of them are constantly breaking down and new ones are just as rapidly being built up. The necessary material for thiscontinuous rebuilding being supplied from the blood stream. Hence it can readily be seenthat, if the blood lacks the necessary quantities of these active, life-giving, inorganicelements, the rebuilding process cannot proceed in a normal orderly manner, and theresulting disturbance of the bodily rhythm gives rise to what is called “disease” in one ofits many and varied forms.

A shortage or deficiency of one or several of these vital mineral substances may arise from a variety of causes; injuries, self-poisoning and obscure influences which in manyinstances science has not yet been able to explain. The fact we have to recognise is that“disease” - the word simply means lack of ease - indicates a disturbance of the bodilyrhythm; a disturbance which interferes with the assimilation and transport of the vitalmaterials essential for the repair and maintenance of living tissues. Obviously, if thecells do not receive their proper nourishment and are not cleansed of the poisonous wastematerial resulting from cellular activity, ill-health becomes inevitable.

THE TWELVE TISSUE SALTS

The twelve biochemic remedies of Schuessler, sometimes referred to as mineral salts or tissue salts (we use the term, tissue salts), are absolutely harmless; they are not drugsin any sense of the word. They simply provide to the system the deficient inorganicelements, prepared homoeopathically, in an extremely finely subdivided form - a formwhich ensures their ready assimilation and a speedy restoration of that balance andharmony in the system which spell health and happiness.

There is nothing miraculous in the action of these remedies; their virtues are derived from the application of principles based upon the laws of nature. They are to the ailingwhat food is to the starving man. They bring ease by the logical process of removing the
cause of disease. The biochemic system of medicine rests upon a firm foundation; it hasstood the test of searching investigation. The more recentdiscoveries in the field ofbiological research, and the findings of present-day biochemists, confirm its teachings. Infact, later discoveries, made after his death, serve to pay handsome tribute to thewonderful insight and true medical genius of Dr. W. H. Schuessler, the founder ofBiochemistry.

INORGANIC CONSTITUENTS OF CELLS

The principal inorganic materials of nerve-cells are Mag-nesia phos., Kali phos.,
Natrum and Ferrum. Muscele-cells contain the same, with the addition of Kali mur.
Connective tissue-cells have for their specific substance Silica, while that of the
elastic tissue-cells is probably Calcarea fluor. In bone-cells we have Calcarea fluor
and Magnesia phos. and a large proportion of Calcarea phos. This latter is found in small
quantities in the cells of muscle, nerve, brain and connective tissue. Cartilage and
mucous cells have for their specific inorganic material Natrum mur., which is found
also in all solid and fluid parts of the body. Hair and the crystalline lens contain,
among other inorganic substances, also Ferrum. The carbonates, as such, are, according
to Moleschott, without any influence in the process of cell-formation

PREPARATION AND DOSE

The Tissue Remedies are prepared for therapeutic purposes, like all homoeopathic
remedies, according to the decimal or centesimal scale in trituration or dilution.

SCHUSSLER’S OWN PROCEDURE

At first Schussler began with the sixth centesimal or twelfth decimal trituration; but
he, very early in his practice, adopted the sixth decimal preparation as the one mostQu,


generally useful. Lately the lower triturations of Potassium and Sodium salts, the third
decimal, of others the fourth and fifth, have been productive of equally good results. In
the last edition of his “Abgekurzte Therapie” he says on this point: “In my practice |
employ the sixth decimal trituration generally. Ferrumphos., Silicea and Calcarea fluar,
I usually give in the 12th trituration. In acute diseases, a dose consisting of a powder,
size of a pea, should be given every hour or two; in chronic diseases 3 or 4 times daily.
The powder may be given dry on the tongue, or dissolved in a spoonful of water.”

We, ourselves, have had the most satisfactory results from the sixth decimal
trituration, rarely going higher, at times lower, and generally we prefer to give the
selected remedy in solution by dissolving a good-sized powder in a tumbler, half full of
water, and administering teaspoonful doses every hour or two.

These triturations may be moulded into tablets usually of one grain each; the dose
being two or three taken dry on tongue or dissolved in water.

If liquid solutions are used, a few drops may be dissolved in water, or pellets or disks
may be saturated and given in that way. The latter is especially to be recommended with
children.

FREQUENCY OF DOSES
(a) In acute cases - a dose every hour or two
(b) In severe, painful affections - a dose every ten to fifteen minutes
(c) In chronic affections - one to four doses daily

In suitable cases the external use of the remedies is indicated and has been found
useful. For this purpose the lower triturations may be used.

In determining the dose of a biochemic remedy, the amount of the morbid product
involved is no important factor. For instance, a very small deficiency of Natrum mur. in
the cells of the epithelial layer of a serous sac may give rise to a massive serous
exudation; and as minute a supply of Natrum mur. corresponding to the deficiency may
bring about a complete resorption of the exudation.

Guided by the relative quantities of the cell salts, each practitioner can select the
proper dose of the indicated biochemic remedy.

One milligramme of a substance is estimated to contain 16 trillions of molecules.
According to this estimate, the 6th decimal trituration of it would contain about 16
billions; this quantity is more than sufficient to restore disturbed molecular motions to
the normal.

RELATION OF THE BIOCHEMIC TO THE HOMCEOPATHIC TREATMENT

Often the question has been asked, “is Schueslerism Homeopathy?” and it has as
often been answered in the affirmative as in the negative. Schuessler himself claimed
that it is not in any way related to Homoeopathy, claiming for it a separate system of
therapeutics.
Biochemic System of Medicine 663

He claims with others that the Tissue Remedies act by supplying deficiencies. This
jdea, taken literally, seems erroneous; for example, in a disturbance of the molecules of
Natr. mur. there is not necessarily a deficiency in the amount Natr. mur. in the body, but
rather a lack of continuity in the arrangement of the existing molecules in the body. This
salt given as a remedy does not supply a lack or deficiency of salt, as the quantity given
js usually too infinitesimal for the purpose, and were this the case it might be given in
quantity with food and drink with the desired effect. The deficiency that it does supply
in minimal doses is in the arrangement of the equilibrium of the chain of Natr. mur.
molecules in the affected tissues, thus causing them to perform their function properly;
for, since the deficit is a molecular one, the supply must also be molecular.

This idea of the action of remedies is not new, as any one who has carefully perused
the works of that astute observer, Von Grauvogl, can testify. Many of Schussler’s ideas
are foreshadowed in Grauvogl and Hering.

CALCAREA PHOSPHORICA

Synonym : Common Names:
Calcium Phosphate Phosphate of lime

Calc. phos is a nutritive salt absolutely essential to theproper growth and nutrition of
the body. It promotes cell growth, supplying the first basis for the new tissue, hence necessary to initiate growth.
This salt is found in the blood plasma and corpuscles, saliva, gastric juice, bones and
other connective tissue, teeth, milk , etc.
'tcalcarea

This salt works with albumen, carries it to bone tissue or to any part of the body
where it may be needed. It uses albumen as a cement to build up bone structure. Thus it gives solidity to the bones.

Bone is fifty-seven per cent, phosphate of lime, the remainder gelatine; an
albuminous, gluey substance, carbonate of soda, magnesium phosphate and sodium
chloride. Without the lime phosphate no bone can be made. It is the nutritive salt for the
periostium and through it for bones.

Calcarea phos also supplies new blood cells, thus becoming the first remedy in anemia. Without Calc Phos there could be no blood coagulation.

Calcium phosphate is found in gastric juice, and a lack of the proper balance is frequently the cause of indigestion.

Conditions called rheumatism are sometimes due to a deficiency of the cell-salt. It is
well known to Biochemists that a proper balance of sodium phosphate is required to
prevent an acid condition from prevailing, and under certain conditions, when calcium
phosphate for any reason is not present in proper quantities, the affinities draw upon
sodium phosphate in an endeavor to supply the lack, and thus a deficiency in the alkaline
salts ensue, which allows an acid condition to prevail, i.e, rheumatism.

Calcium phosphate is an auxiliary to the therapeutical effects of magnesium
phosphate, as it more nearly resembles that salt than any other. When Magnes. phos. is
clearly indicated, and does not restore the normal condition in a reasonable length of
time, Calc. phos. should be given, for it is quite certain that it has been drawn on from
the blood to assist the work of Magnes. phos., hence the deficiency in the lime-salt.

tissues. This is the remedy for any period of convalescence; its restorative power

always been prized as a restorative.

Another important feature is its restorative power after acute diseases, either
directly or preparing the way for other remedies, by stimulating the system to their
action, thus becoming an important intercurent remedy.

FERRUM PHOSPHORICUM

Synonym : Common Names:
Ferri phosphas Phosphate of Iron

Ferr Phos is the pre-eminent Biochemic First Aid. It is the oxygen carrier. It enters into the composition of haemoglobin. It takes up oxygen from the air inhaled by the lungs and carries it inthe blood stream to all parts of the body thus helps to sustain life. Without a proper balance ofiron in the blood, health cannot be maintained.When a deficiency in this cell-salt occurs, the circulation is increased, for the blood tries tocarry enough oxygen to all the tissues of the body with the limited amount of iron at hand, and in order to do so must move rapidly; exactly as seven men must move faster in order toaccomplish as much work as could ten, moving at a slower pace.

This increased motion being changed to heat, by the law of the conservation of energy, is called fever. It is not the fever or heat alone that causes the condition of “notat ease “ in the patient, but the deficiency in iron molecules, and a consequent lack ofoxygen. This molecular disturbance soon breaks up continuity of other cell-salts. Adeficiency in potassium chloride nearly always follows a deficiency in iron, unless themissing links be quickly supplied. The cell-salt potassium chloride controls the fibrin inthe circulation, and when the particles of salt fall below the standard, a portion of fibrin,not having workmen to use it, becomes a disturbing element and leaves the vitalcirculation. If it is thrown off through the lungs, a cough is produced (nature’s spasmodiceffort to get rid of the heteroplasm). In some instances the lung tissue becomes soirritated and inflamed that the doctors declare that the ’ cold ’ settled on the lungs andgave the patient the pneumonia. If the fibrinous exudation is thrown off through thenasal passages, it is called catarrh. The word catarrh is from the Greek, and simplymeans to “drop down,” therefore, is no help to the pathology of the condition.

A lack of ferrum molecules, viz.: a proper balance in the blood, is the cause of“colds.” When a deficiency of iron occurs, nature, or the natural law, draws the bloodaway from the outer parts, the skin, in order to carry on the process of life more perfectlyabout the heart, lungs, liver, stomach, brain, etc. A lack of blood in the minute blood-vessels of the skin allows the pores to close, and waste matter that should escape by thisroute is turned upon the inner organs. This accumulation, together with certain organicmatter thrown out of the blood, caused by deficienciesin certain inorganic salts, formsthe exudation of colds, catarrh, pneumonia, plourisy, ete.For all such conditions, whenever there isinflammation, under whatever name it may be known, Ferr. phos. is the chief remedy. Hence Iron Phosphate (Ferrum Phos) is considered as “Inflammation Remedy”It gives strength and toughness to the circular walls of the blood vessels, especiallythe arteries. Freely circulating, oxygen-rich blood is essential to health and life, and forthis reason Ferr Phos should always be considered as a supplementary remedy, nomatter what other treatment may be indicated by the symptoms.

~ KALI MURIATICUM

Synonym : Common Names:
Potassium Chloride Chloride of Potash

It is contained in nearly all the cells and is chemically related to fibrin. Disturbances in its molecular action cause fibrinous exudations.

When the cells of the epidermis, in consequence of any irritation, lose molecules of Kali mur. then the fibrin comes to the surface as a
white or whitish-grey exudation. This, when dried, forms a mealy eruption. If the irritation extends to
the tissues beneath the epidermis, both fibrin and serum will exude, and the affected part of the skin
will be pushed up in the form of blisters. This is exactly what takes place in small-pox, cow-pox vaccine disease. Similar processes may take
place in and below epithelial cells.

This gives the indication for it in catarrhs, in croupous and diphtheritic exudations, and in the second stage of inflammation of serous membranes when the exudation is plastic or fibrinous in character. These are practically the whole of the cardinal
indications in which Kali m. has been prescribed.

If the integrity of the affected tissue again restored by the administration of Kali Mur. molecules, then a reabsorbtion ot throwing off the exudation occurs probably by the formation of hydrochloric acid formed by one part of chlorine from the KCL with hydrogen.

Kali Mur is the remedy for sluggish conditions. It combines with the organic substance fibrin. Thus a deficiency of this tissue salt causes fibrin to become nor- functional, and to be thrown off in the form of thick, white discharges, giving rise te catarrhs and similar symptoms affecting the skin and mucous membranes.

Its action is complementary to that of Calc Sulph, as both remedies are concerned with cleansing and purifying the blood. In conditions calling for Kali Mur, the blood tends to thicken and to form clots. In alternation with Ferr Phos it is frequently needed for the
treatment of children’s ailments.

Kali Mur is the remedy for thick, white fibrinous discharges. Other prominent symptoms are a white-coated tongue and light-coloured stools (lack of bile). Torpidity of the liver is another indication. In alternation with Ferr Phos it is frequently needed in the treatment of inflammatory diseases, particularly those affecting respiration - coughs, colds, sore throats, tonsillitis, bronchitis, etc., also for children’s ailments such as measles and chicken pox and where there are soft swellings, e.g. mumps, croup.

Kali Mur is concerned with the production of saliva and is therefore important in the early stages of digestion. The symptoms may be worse after eating fatty or rich foods and

Kali Muriaticum orn 677

there may be lack of appetite. With Nat Mur it is utilised in the production of hydrochloric acid, and is thus an essential link in the process of digestion. This tissue salt is useful as a first aid for the treatment of burns. Kali Mur & Ferrum Phos the top two tissue salts for colds. Kali Mur for the runny nose. Sinusitis, the mucous looks like uncooked or slightly soft-boiled egg white, mucous clear to white but not sticky. Mucous can get thick white later on.

MAGNESIA PHOSPHORICA

Synonym : Common Names:
Magnesium Phosphate Phosphate of magnesia

Molecules of magnesium phosphate are found chiefly in the white fibres of the nerves and muscles. The white fibres seem to be
controlled by the molecular action of the magnesia cell-salt.When a deficiency in this
salt occurs, these white fibres contract, and produce a condition called spasms, or cramps.
Of course, it is simply nature’s language, saying: “I want more magnesium phosphate”.
Hence it is a remedy for cramps, convulsions, and other nervous phenomena.

When a deficiency of magnesium
phosphate occurs in the muscular tissue of the walls of the stomach, the white fibres
draw up, contract, and reduce the cavity of the stomach. Now, in order to meet this
condition and prevent a collapse, gas is formed by a natural process from the material at
hand, and by expansion produces a counter-force. Magnesium phosphate relieves such
conditions almost instantly by supplying deficiencies.

This wonderful curative agent is the true antispasmodic remedy. It has cured cases
of chorea, or St. Vitus’ dance, in from two to four weeks. For all heart troubles, so-called,
caused by a distension of the cardiac portion of the stomach, and thus interfering with
the action of the heart, it is the sovereign remedy.

Mag Phos is indicated for nerve pains, such as neuralgia, neuritis and sciatica, and
headaches accompanied by shooting, darting stabs of pain. It relieves muscular
twitching, cramps, hiccups, convulsive fits of coughing and those sudden, sharp twinges
of pain that are so distressing. It also relieves menstrual pains. Stomach cramps and
flatulence respond to treatment with this tissue salt.

The only exception to this rule of speedy cures by administering this remedy is where
the blood has furnished calcium phosphate as a substitute, in an effort to supply the
deficiency. Calcium phosphate more nearly corresponds to magnesium phosphate than
any other salt; therefore, when magnesium phosphate does not act very promptly,
calcium phosphate should be given, in order that the chain of molecules may be
completed in both of the disturbed salts,

Its main function is in connection with the nervous system where it supplements the action of Kali Phos.

NATRUM PHOSPHORICUM

Synonym : Common Names:
Sodium phosphate Phosphate of soda

This salt is found in the blood, muscles, nerve and brain-cells, as well as in the intercellular fluids. Through the presence of this
salt, lactic acid is decomposed into carbonic acid and water. It absorbs the carbonic acid, taking up two molecules for
every molecule of itself, and carries it to the lungs, where the oxygen of the air sets the carbonic acid free in exchange for oxygen, which latter is taken up by the iron contained in the blood corpuscles. Any deficiency in this prevents this chemical change, and the lactic
acid remains as such. An acid state of the system now prevails; rheumatism, dyspepsia, intestinal troubles, etc., ensue. According to Schussler, by the administration of molecular doses of this drug, this catalytic action is at once restored - the acid state ceases, and the
rheumatic and other symptoms subside.

Uric acid is kept soluble in the blood by the presence of the phosphate of soda and the natural temperature of the blood. Whenever there is a deficiency of this salt, uric acid is combined with the soda, forming the urate of soda, an insoluble salt and deposited near the points producing gout and acute inflammatory rheumatism.

Natrum phosph. serves to emulsify fatty acids; it is therefore a remedy for all dyspeptic conditions traceable to fats, or such as are aggravated by their use.

Natrum phos, is the remedy for conditions arising from excess of lactic acid. It prevents inspissation of the bile and mucus with crystallization of cholesterin in the gall duct and will thus remove the cause of many cases of jaundice, hepatic colic,
bilious headache and imperfect assimilation of fats from lack of bile.
It is useful gout, as well as in acute and chronic articular rheumatism, being thus a remedy for the so-called acid diathesis.

NATRUM SULPHURICUM

Synonym : Common Names:
Sodium sulphate Glauber’s salt, Sulphate of soda

This inorganic salt is found in the intercellular fluids, and its principal office is toregulate the water in the tissue, blood and fluids of the body. Sodium sulphate regulates theamount by having the power to eliminate any excess that may, from any cause, be present. Onemolecule of sodium sulphate has the power to take up and carry out of the organism twomolecules of water. So sodium sulphate must be present in proper quantity in the body. Adeficiency of this salt prevents the elimination of such water from the tissue as is produced byoxidation of organic matter (while sodium chloride properly distributes the water in tissue, as has been shown) and thus will arise a hydrogenoid condition.

Biochemistry has established the fact that chills and fever (or ague), cholera, yellowfever and all ailments incident to hot weather, are caused by an excess of water in theblood, and probably in intercellular fluids: and that all such conditions arise from theinability of the digestion and assimilation to furnish sufficient quantity of sodiumsulphate to carry off the excess of water breathed into the blood through the lungs.

When the blood becomes overcharged with water, of course, the various tissues of thebody must suffer from lack of proper nourishment. This sets up a panic. Now, as thewater-carriers are not present in sufficient quantities to throw out the excess in the natural way, nature does the next best thing — causes a spasm of the vascular, nervousand muscular systems, and thus, by violent effort, throws out the excess of water; hencethe profuse perspiration which follows the chill. Where Natr. sulph. is not given tosupply the workmen, and thus keep out an excess of water, the chill will recur in aboutfortyeight hours, simply because that much time is required to again overcharge theblood with water.

So we find that among the inorganic salt-workmen in the human economy, sodium
sulphate works with water, keeps bile and pancreatic juice at normal consistency,
regulates the supply of water in intercellular fluid, and eliminates the excess of water
from the blood, when present in proper quantity.

In biochemic system of medicne Sodium Sulphate (Nat Sulph) is considered as “The
Elimination Salt”

The three natrum salts work in the body as follows,

Natrum Phos creates the water by splitting up of lactic acid; Nat Mur distributes the
water through the system. Nat. Sulph. regulates the quantity of water in the organism.

CHARACTERISTIC INDICATIONS

3. The chief characteristic is a dirty greenish-gray or greenish-brown coating on the root of the tongue indicating an excess of bile (while a white or gray coating denotes a deficiency of bile, and requires Kali mur.).

4. Biliousness, caused from the liver secreting an excess of bile. Bitter taste in mouth. Mouth full of slime. Bilious vomiting. Bilious diarrhoea.

feels better in dry, warm atmosphere. Complaints from living in damp buildings, basements, etc., or from eating water-plants, fish, etc. Symptoms aggravated by the use of water in any form. Conditions which tend to increase the water in the system, such as living in low, marshy places, “ague districts “ will cause a. molecular disturbance of Natr. sulph.

SILICEA

Synonym : Common Names:
Silica Silicious earth, pure flint or quartz

Silicea is found in the hair, nails, skin, periosteum, neurilemma (nerve sheath), and a trace in the bone _ tissue. This salt is
indicated in all suppurative processes until the infiltrated parts have fully discharged
the accumulation of decaying organic matter that may have arrived at a given point during nature’s effort to eliminate it
from the system. In the first stage of any swelling, Ferr. phos. and Kali mur. should be
given, but should these salts fail to abort the process, Silicea should at once be given. The
theory is, that the particles of silica, being sharp-cornered, accumulate under the
intelligent operations of nature’s law of affinity or attraction and act as a lancet,
thus cutting a way through the tissue, skin, etc., for the escape of the non-
functional organic matter. But in order to carry on any work, nature must have
tools to work with. When silica is present in proper quantities, the process of
suppuration is carried on in a normal manner. When a deficiency of silica occurs,
suppuration is retarded; the greater the deficiency, the greater and more stubborn and
painful the swelling or part at which the matter is attempting to escape.

A deficiency of silica in the connective tissue between the cerebrum and cerebellum
produces a mental condition in which thinking is difficult. By supplying silica in
molecular form, the chemical affinity is restored and normal thought again established.

Silicea has also the power to reabsorb a bloody or sero-albuminous exudate, existing
within the tissues by means of the lymphatics. Here it often follows Calc. phos.

Silicea cures chronic gouty rheumatic affections by means of its stimulating effects of
the involved connective tissue cells, compelling these to throw off the accumulated urates
through the lymphatics.

Silicea can restore suppressed foot-sweats, and in this way be an indirect remedy for
diseases resulting from suppression of foot-sweat, for instance: amblyopia, cataract,
paralyses, etc.

If the cells of any part of the connective tissue show a lack of Silicia molecules, they
atrophy in consequence.

Its action is deep and long-lasting.

Psoric Constitution (Calc. ost., Hell. N., Psor, Sil, Sulph.) The persons having this
constitution are over sensitive both physically and mentally and frequently suffer from
functional disturbances arising from emotional disturbances. Skin dry, unwashed
appearing with numerous eruptions. Itching, ameliorated by scratching, but skin burns
and smarts afterwards. Hands and feet burn, flushes of heat, especially over face. Desires
hot foods and meats. Cannot stand still; the patient must walk or lean against something
if he is on his feet. Very much susceptible to cold; Complaints, ameliorated by heat;
aggravated by winter; ameliorated by summer. A psoric patient is always afraid of dying
but lives on for years.
